title: Inside Bolt: From near-death to one of the fastest-growing products in history | Eric Simons
key_insights: Building deep technology first can pay off massively if you survive long enough to find the right use case
AI coding tools work best when compute runs locally in the browser rather than on cloud servers for speed and reliability
Non-technical product managers are often more successful with AI coding tools than developers because they excel at articulating requirements
Small, long-tenured teams with high context can scale much faster than large teams with frequent turnover
The deterministic nature of code makes it ideal for AI training compared to other domains like law
Daily all-hands meetings for the entire company can be effective during periods of extreme growth to minimize communication loss
Anthropic's Claude Sonnet was the breakthrough model that made reliable AI code generation possible
AI coding represents a fundamental shift from human-first to AI-first development with human assistance

memorable_quotes: It was kind of like, Bolt's this overnight success, seven years in the making.
The company was on the verge of going under when we launched Bolt, and what ended up happening is, in the first two months it went from zero to 20 million of ARR.
Most importantly, it's been the people. It's rare to find startups where you have the core group of five, six, seven people that have been there for five years plus.

summary: Eric Simons shares how StackBlitz's seven-year journey building browser-based development tools culminated in Bolt, an AI coding platform that grew from 0 to 40M ARR in five months. The conversation explores the technical breakthroughs, organizational strategies, and future implications of AI-first software development.
